direction.raw_text: . BAILEY'S PRIVATE OFFICE  DAY MEDIUM SHOT George's father is seated behind his desk, nervously drawing swirls on a pad. He looks tired and worried. He is a gentle man in his forties, an idealist, stubborn only for other people's rights.  Nearby, in a throne-like wheelchair, behind which stands the goon who furnishes the motive power, sits Henry F. Potter, his squarish derby hat on his head. The following dialogue is fast and heated, as though the argument had been in process for some time.

dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUILDING AND LOAN  DAY CLOSE SHOT  SIDEWALK An iron grill blocks the street entrance to the Building and Loan.  It has been locked. A crowd of men and women are waiting around the grill. They are simply-dressed people, to whom their savings are a matter of life and death.  George comes in with an assumed cheerful manner. The people look at him silently, half shamefaced, but grimly determined on their rights. In their hearts there is panic and fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one answers. He quickly unlocks the grill door and pushes it open. Followed by the crowd, George runs upstairs and into the outer offices of the Building and Loan.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, everybody. Mrs. Thompson, how are you? Charlie? What's the matter here, can't you get in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OUTER OFFICE  BUILDING AND LOAN  DAY MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT George, followed by the still-silent people, comes in. Uncle Billy is standing in the doorway to his private office, taking a drink from a bottle. He motions to George to join him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points to George's office. George turns back cheerfully to the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George vaults over the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people ignore George and remain standing in front of the teller's window. They all have their passbooks out. George hurries into his office where Uncle Billy is waiting for him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this, Uncle Billy? A holiday?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: George...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on in, everybody. That's right, just come in.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now look, why don't you all sit down. There are a lot of seats over there. Just make yourselves at home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: George, can I see you a minute?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND UNCLE BILLY GEORGE Why didn't you call me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The telephone rings. Uncle Billy picks it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I just did, but they said you left. This is a pickle, George, this is a pickle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right now, what happened? How did it start?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How does anything like this ever start?  All I know is the bank called our loan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About an hour ago. I had to hand over all our cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All of it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every cent of it, and it still was less than we owe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Holy mackerel!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And then I got scared, George, and closed the doors. I... I... I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The whole town's gone crazy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, hello? George... it's Potter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S LIBRARY  DAY MEDIUM SHOT Potter seated behind his desk, his goon alongside him. Standing in front of the desk is a distinguished-looking man, obviously the president of the bank. He is mopping his brow with his handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: George, there is a rumor around town that you've closed your doors. Is that true?  Oh, well, I'm very glad to hear that...  George, are you all right? Do you need any police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND UNCLE BILLY GEORGE (on phone) Police? What for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE  DAY MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT  POTTER TALKING ON PHONE POTTER Well, mobs get pretty ugly sometimes, you know. George, I'm going all out to help in this crisis. I've just guaranteed the bank sufficient funds to meet their needs.  They'll close up for a week, and then reopen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND UNCLE BILLY GEORGE (to Uncle Billy) He just took over the bank.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  POTTER ON PHONE POTTER I may lose a fortune, but I'm willing to guarantee your people too. Just tell them to bring their shares over here and I will pay them fifty cents on the dollar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND UNCLE BILLY GEORGE (furiously) Aw, you never miss a trick, do you, Potter? Well, you're going to miss this one. George bangs the receiver down and turns to meet Uncle Billy's anxious look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE CLOSEUP  POTTER ON PHONE POTTER If you close your doors before six P.M. you will never reopen. He realizes George has hung up, and clicks the phone furiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND UNCLE BILLY UNCLE BILLY George, was it a nice wedding? Gosh, I wanted to be there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An ominous SOUND of angry voices comes from the other room. George and Uncle Billy exit from George's office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... (looks at string on Uncle Billy's finger) ...you can take this one off now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OUTER OFFICE  BUILDING AND LOAN  DAY MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT More people have crowded around the counter. Their muttering stops and they stand silent and grim. There is panic in their faces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As George speaks, sirens are heard passing in the street below.  The crowd turn to the windows, then back to George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary and Ernie have come into the room during this scene. Mary stands watching silently.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now, just remember that this thing isn't as black as it appears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have some news for you, folks. I've just talked to old man Potter, and he's guaranteed cash payments at the bank. The bank's going to reopen next week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, George, I got my money here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did he guarantee this place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, no, Charlie. I didn't even ask him.  We don't need Potter over here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take mine now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but you... you... you're thinking of this place all wrong. As if I had the money back in a safe. The money's not here. Your money's in Joe's house... (to one of the men) ...right next to yours. And in the Kennedy house, and Mrs. Macklin's house, and a hundred others. Why, you're lending them the money to build, and then, they're going to pay it back to you as best they can. Now what are you going to do? Foreclose on them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got two hundred and forty-two dollars in here, and two hundred and forty-two dollars isn't going to break anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ANOTHER ANGLE GEORGE (handing him a slip) Okay, Tom. All right. Here you are. You sign this. You'll get your money in sixty days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a commotion at the outer doors. A man (Randall) comes in and makes his way up to Tom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few other people start for the door.  CAMERA PANS WITH George as he vaults over the counter quickly, speaking to the people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The people are still trying to get out, but some of them have stood still, listening to him. George has begun to make an impression on them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this scene Mary has come up behind the counter. Suddenly, as the people once more start moving toward the door, she holds up a roll of bills and calls out
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George jumps over the counter and takes the money from Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George starts rapidly to count out the money. Tom throws his passbook on the counter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary turns and slips out through the crowd, followed by Ernie. George hands the two hundred and forty-two dollars to Tom, and speaks to Ed, the next in line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy takes out his wallet and takes out all the cash he's got.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sixty days?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, now that's what you agreed to when you bought your shares.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom... Tom, did you get your money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I did. Old man Potter'll pay fifty cents on the dollar for every share you got. (shows bills)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ad lib) Fifty cents on the dollar!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, cash!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to George) Well, what do you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, Tom, you have to stick to your original agreement. Now give us sixty days on this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning to Randall) Okay, Randall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON Are you going to go to Potter's?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better to get half than nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom! Tom! Randall! Now wait... now listen... now listen to me. I beg of you not to do this thing. If Potter gets hold of this Building and Loan there'll never be another decent house built in this town. He's already got charge of the bank.  He's got the bus line. He's got the department stores. And now he's after us.  Why? Well, it's very simple. Because we're cutting in on his business, that's why.  And because he wants to keep you living in his slums and paying the kind of rent he decides.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Joe, you lived in one of his houses, didn't you? Well, have you forgotten? Have you forgotten what he charged you for that broken-down shack? (to Ed) Here, Ed. You know, you remember last year when things weren't going so well, and you couldn't make your payments. You didn't lose your house, did you? Do you think Potter would have let you keep it? (turns to address the room again) Can't you understand what's happening here? Don't you see what's happening? Potter isn't selling. Potter's buying! And why? Because we're panicky and he's not.  That's why. He's picking up some bargains.  Now, we can get through this thing all right. We've got to stick together, though. We've got to have faith in each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON But my husband hasn't worked in over a year, and I need money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How am I going to live until the bank opens?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got doctor bills to pay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need cash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't feed my kids on faith.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much do you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! I got two thousand dollars! Here's two thousand dollars. This'll tide us over until the bank reopen. (to Tom) All right, Tom, how much do you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (doggedly) Two hundred and forty-two dollars!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pleading) Aw, Tom, just enough to tide you over till the bank reopens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll take two hundred and forty-two dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That'll close my account.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your account's still here. That's a loan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. All right, Ed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I got three hundred dollars here, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, now, Ed... what'll it take till the bank reopens? What do you need?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I suppose twenty dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twenty dollars. Now you're talking. Fine.  Thanks, Ed. (to Mrs. Thompson, next in line) All right, now, Mrs. Thompson. How much do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON But it's your own money, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind about that. How much do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON I can get along with twenty, all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (counting it out) Twenty dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . THOMPSON And I'll sign a paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have to sign anything. I know you'll pay it back when you can. That's okay. (to woman next in line) All right, Mrs. Davis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . DAVIS Could I have seventeen-fifty?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seven... (he kisses her) Bless your heart, Of course you can have it. You got fifty cents? (counting) Seven...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OUTER OFFICE BUILDING AND LOAN  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT George, Uncle Billy and Cousin Tilly are behind the counter, watching the minute hand of a clock on the wall as George counts off the seconds. Cousin Eustace is ready to close the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cousin Eustace slams and locks the door, and scurries around the counter to join the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy is taking a drink out of his bottle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The four of them parade through the office; George puts the two dollars in the safe.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (excitedly) We're going to make it, George. They'll never close us up today!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (counting) Six... five... four... three... two... one... Bingo!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We made it! Look... (holds up two bills) ... look, we're still in business! We've still got two bucks left!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, let's have some of that. Get some glasses, Cousin Tilly. (to Uncle Billy) We're a couple of financial wizards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Those Rockefellers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get a tray for these great big important simoleons.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll save them for seed. A toast! They raise their glasses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A toast! A toast to Papa Dollar and to Mama Dollar, and if you want the old Building and Loan to stay in business, you better have a family real quick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish they were rabbits.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish they were too. Okay, let's put them in the safe and see what happens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: GROUP AROUND THE SAFE DOOR As George comes out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George rushes into his office to look out the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (handing out cigars) Wedding cigars!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (startled) Oh-oh... wedding! Holy mackerel, I'm married! Where's Mary? Mary... (he runs around looking for her) Poor Mary. Look, I've got a train to catch. (looks at his watch) Well, the train's gone. I wonder if Ernie's still here with his taxicab?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on telephone) George, there's a call for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, will you get my wife on the phone?  She's probably over at her mother's.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Bailey is on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE MEDIUM CLOSEUP  GEORGE IS THOROUGHLY RATTLED GEORGE I don't want Mrs. Bailey. I want my wife.  Mrs. Bailey! Oh, that's my wife! Here, I'll take it in here. (picks up phone) Mary? Hello. Listen, dear, I'm sorry...  What? Come home? What home? Three-twenty Sycamore? Well, what... whose home is that? The Waldorf Hotel, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OLD GRANVILLE HOUSE  NIGHT MEDIUM LONG SHOT An old-fashioned, run-down house, unpainted and warped by the weather. It once had class but has not been lived in for years.  This is the house that George and Mary will live in from now on.  The rain is pouring down. A faint glow of light shines out from bottom windows. George hurries into scene. He stops to make sure it is the right number before going up the steps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SIDE OF HOUSE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Bert and man working in rain, sorting through travel posters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A sharp whistle is heard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, this is the company's posters, and the company won't like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How would you like to get a ticket next week? Haven't you any romance in you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I have, but I got rid of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reading poster) Liver pills! Who wants to see liver pills on their honeymoon? What? They want romantic places, beautiful places...  places George wants to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: WINDOW OF HOUSE Ernie is leaning from the window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Bert, here he comes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: BERT AND MAN BERT Come on, we got to get this up. He's coming.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The groom, idiot. Come on, get that ladder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (disgustedly) What are they  ducks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: SIDE PORCH OF HOUSE Bert and the man are putting up travel posters to cover up the broken windows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get that ladder up here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right  all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry up... hurry up... hurry up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm hurrying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: George is approaching the front door of the house, on which a sign is hanging: "Bridal Suite." Ernie looks out through the curtain covering the broken glass of the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernie opens the door, revealing himself as a homemade butler. This has been accomplished by rolling up his pants and putting on an old coachman's hat. George enters.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hiya... Good evening, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Entray, monsieur, entray.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GRANVILLE HOUSE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE ENTERS The house is carpetless, empty  the rain and wind cause funny noises upstairs. A huge fire is burning in the fireplace. Near the fireplace a collection of packing boxes are heaped together in the shape of a small table and covered with a checkered oil cloth. It is set for two. A bucket with ice and a champagne bottle sit on the table as well as a bowl of caviar. Two small chickens are impaled on a spit over the fire. A phonograph is playing on a box, and a string from the phonograph is turning the chickens on the spit. The phonograph is playing "Song of the Islands." Mary is standing near the fireplace looking as pretty as any bride ever looked. She is smiling at George, who has been slowly taking in the whole set-up. Through a door he sees the end of a cheap bed, over the back of which is a pair of pajamas and a nightie. Ernie exits and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They rush into each other's arms and hold each other in ecstasy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (tears in her eyes) Welcome home, Mr. Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (overcome) Well, I'll be... Mary, Mary, where did you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SIDE OF HOUSE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Bert and Ernie, standing in the pouring rain, start singing "I Love You Truly."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOUSE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND MARY They remain embraced.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mary...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember the night we broke the windows in this old house? This is what I wished for.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darling, you're wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SIDE OF HOUSE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT  BERT AND ERNIE They finish their song, and Ernie kisses Bert on the forehead. Bert slams Ernie's hat on his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . SLUM STREET BEDFORD FALLS  DAY  TWO YEARS LATER MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT In front of one of the miserable shacks that line the street are two vehicles. One of them is George Bailey's rickety car, and the other is an even more rickety truck piled high with household goods. The Martini family is moving. The family consists of Martini, his wife and four kid of various ages, from two to ten.  George and Mary are helping the Martinis move. About a dozen neighbors crowd around. Martini and George, assisted by three of the Martini children, are carrying out the last of the furniture.  As they emerge from the house, one of the neighbors, Schultz, calls out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary gets in the front seat of the car, with the baby in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The family goat gets in the back seat with the three kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rickety caravan starts off down the street, to the cheers of the neighbors.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Martini, you rented a new house?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rent? (to George) You hear what he say, Mr. Bailey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I own the house. Me, Giuseppe Martini. I own my own house. No more we live like pigs in thisa Potter's Field. Hurry, Maria.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on... (to Mary) Bring the baby. (to Martini) I'll bring the kids in the car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, thank you, Mr. Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, kids  here  get in here. Now get right up on the seat there. Get the...  get the goat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, everybody!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All in...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BAILEY PARK  DAY CLOSE SHOT Sign hanging from a tree "Welcome to Bailey Park." CAMERA PANS TO follow George's car and the old truck laden with furniture as they pass  we hear Martini's voice singing "O Sole Mio." Bailey Park is a district of new small houses, not all alike, but each individual. New lawns here and there, and young trees. It has the promise when built up of being a pleasant little middle class section.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARTINI'S NEW HOUSE  DAY MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT George and Mary are on the porch of the new house, with the Martinis lined up before them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. and Mrs. Martini, welcome home. The Martinis cross themselves.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STREET  BAILEY PARK  DAY CLOSE SHOT Sam Wainwright is standing in front of his big black town car. Sam is the epitome of successful, up-and-coming businessman. His wife, in the car, is a very attractive, sophisticated-looking lady, dripping with furs and jewels. Sam is watching George across the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That old George... he's always making a speech. (to George) Hee-haw! (wiggles his hands)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NEW HOUSE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  MARY AND GEORGE ON PORCH GEORGE (to Mary) Sam Wainwright!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Martini crosses herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Martinis cross themselves, shaking hands all around. The kids enter, with screams of delight. Mrs. Martini kisses Mary.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, who cares. (to Mrs. Martini, giving her loaf of bread) Bread! That this house may never know hunger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (giving her salt) Salt! That life may always have flavor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing bottle to Martini) And wine!  That joy and prosperity may reign forever. Enter the Martini castle!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE IN BANK  DAY CLOSE SHOT Potter seated in his wheelchair at his desk, with his goon beside him.  His rent collector, Reineman, is talking, pointing to maps spread out on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A buzzer is heard, and Potter snaps on the dictaphone on his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reineman exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He flips the switch on the dictaphone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Mr. Potter, it's no skin off my nose. I'm just your little rent collector.  But you can't laugh off this Bailey Park any more. Look at it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Congressman Blatz is here to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to dictaphone) Oh, tell the congressman to wait. (to Reineman) Go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fifteen years ago, a half-dozen houses stuck here and there. (indicating map) There's the old cemetery, squirrels, buttercups, daisies. Used to hunt rabbits there myself. Look at it today. Dozens of the prettiest little homes you ever saw.  Ninety per cent owned by suckers who used to pay rent to you. Your Potter's Field, my dear Mr. Employer, is becoming just that. And are the local yokels making with those David and Goliath wisecracks!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, they are, are they? Even though they know the Baileys haven't made a dime out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know very well why. The Baileys were all chumps. Every one of these homes is worth twice what it cost the Building and Loan to build. If I were you, Mr. Potter...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) Well, you are not me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as he leaves) As I say, it's no skin off my nose. But one of these days this bright young man is going to be asking George Bailey for a job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT Potter is lighting a big cigar which he has just given George. The goon is beside Potter's chair, as usual.

direction.raw_text: As they shake hands, George feels a physical revulsion. Potter's hand feels like a cold mackerel to him. In that moment of physical contact he knows he could never be associated with this man.  George drops his hand with a shudder. He peers intently into Potter's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He turns and shouts at the goon, impassive as ever beside Potter's wheelchair.

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, sir. Quite a cigar, Mr. Potter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You like it? I'll send you a box.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously) Well, I... I suppose I'll find out sooner or later, but just what exactly did you want to see me about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) George, now that's just what I like so much about you. (pleasantly and smoothly) George, I'm an old man, and most people hate me. But I don't like them either, so that makes it all even. You know just as well as I do that I run practically everything in this town but the Bailey Building and Loan. You know, also, that for a number of years I've been trying to get control of it... or kill it. But I haven't been able to do it. You have been stopping me. In fact, you have beaten me, George, and as anyone in this county can tell you, that takes some doing. Take during the depression, for instance. You and I were the only ones that kept our heads. You saved the Building and Loan, and I saved all the rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Well, most people say you stole all the rest.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The envious ones say that, George, the suckers. Now, I have stated my side very frankly. Now, let's look at your side.  Young man, twenty- seven, twenty-eight...  married, making, say... forty a week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indignantly) Forty-five!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forty-five. Forty-five. Out of which, after supporting your mother, and paying your bills, you're able to keep, say, ten, if you skimp. A child or two comes along, and you won't even be able to save the ten. Now, if this young man of twenty-eight was a common, ordinary yokel, I'd say he was doing fine. But George Bailey is not a common, ordinary yokel. He's an intelligent, smart, ambitious young man  who hates his job  who hates the Building and Loan almost as much as I do. A young man who's been dying to get out on his own ever since he was born. A young man... the smartest one of the crowd, mind you, a young man who has to sit by and watch his friends go places, because he's trapped.  Yes, sir, trapped into frittering his life away playing nursemaid to a lot of garlic-eaters.  Do I paint a correct picture, or do I exaggerate?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (mystified) Now what's your point, Mr. Potter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My point? My point is, I want to hire you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dumbfounded) Hire me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you to manage my affairs, run my properties. George, I'll start you out at twenty thousand dollars a year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flabbergasted) Twenty thou... twenty thousand dollars a year?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't mind living in the nicest house in town, buying your wife a lot of fine clothes, a couple of business trips to New York a year, maybe once in a while Europe. You wouldn't mind that, would you, George?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Would I? (looking around skeptically) You're not talking to somebody else around here, are you? You know, this is me, you remember me? George Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yes, George Bailey. Whose ship has just come in  providing he has brains enough to climb aboard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what about the Building and Loan?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, confound it, man, are you afraid of success? I'm offering you a three year contract at twenty thousand dollars a year, starting today. Is it a deal or isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Mr. Potter, I... I... I know I ought to jump at the chance, but I... I just...  I wonder if it would be possible for you to give me twenty- four hours to think it over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure, sure. You go on home and talk about it to your wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like to do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In the meantime, I'll draw up the papers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (offers hand) Okay, George?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking his hand) Okay, Mr. Potter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vehemently) No... no... no... no, now wait a minute, here!  I don't have to talk to anybody!  I know right now, and the answer is no! NO!  Doggone it! (getting madder all the time) You sit around here and you spin your little webs and you think the whole world revolves around you and your money. Well, it doesn't, Mr. Potter!  In the... in the whole vast configuration of things, I'd say you were nothing but a scurvy little spider. You...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...And that goes for you too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And it goes for you too!

result.heading: "PRESIDENT DECORATES HARRY BAILEY LOCAL BOY WINS CONGRESSIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR"

direction.raw_text: : NEWSPAPER The front page of the paper, the Bedford Falls Sentinel. The headline reads: "PRESIDENT DECORATES HARRY BAILEY  LOCAL BOY WINS CONGRESSIONAL MEDAL OF HONOR". The subhead tells of a plan for a giant jubilee and parade, to be followed by a banquet, in honor of Commander Harry Bailey, U.S.N. on his way home from Washington after receiving the Congressional Medal of Honor. There's a large picture of President Truman pinning the coveted medal on Harry's bosom, in the midst of dignitaries; a picture of the transport which Harry saved. Practically the whole front page is devoted to the story.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, sure I am.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then... it's usually customary to bring the money with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, shucks...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looks bewildered) I know I had...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about that one there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hmm? Well, I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT Potter is now behind his desk. He spreads the newspaper out in front of him, muttering as he does so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees the envelope, looks inside at the money. Then, to his goon, indicating the office door:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Potter opens the door just a little, and peers through into the bank.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bailey...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take me back there. Hurry up. (as they go) Come on, look sharp.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BANK  DAY CLOSE SHOT  DEPOSIT SLIP DESK Uncle Billy looks around for the money envelope. It is not there.  He looks puzzled, thinks hard, then a look of concern creeps into his eyes. He starts thumping his pockets, with increasing panic, and looks in the waste paper basket on the floor. He finally rushes through the door and out into the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . POTTER'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  POTTER WATCHING THROUGH THE DOOR POTTER (to goon) Take me back. The goon wheels him back to his desk. He is deep in thought, with a crafty expression on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . STREET  DAY MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT Uncle Billy running across the street in the direction of the Building and Loan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . OUTER OFFICE  BUILDING AND LOAN  DAY CLOSE SHOT George coming from room where he has just left the bank examiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees Violet Bick standing there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hears a noise, and sees Uncle Billy entering the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George and Violet enter his private office. Uncle Billy comes hurrying in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy picks up the phone and speaks distractedly, without knowing what he is saying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up agitatedly, muttering to himself as he goes into his own office. Cousin Tilly and Cousin Eustace look after him, dumbfounded.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Just make yourself at home, Mr. Carter.  I'll get those books for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, hello, Vi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: George, can I see you for a second?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, of course you can. Come on in the office here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uncle Billy, talk to Harry. He's on the telephone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hurry, Uncle Billy, hurry. Long distance, Washington.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, here's Harry on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Harry, your nephew, remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Here he is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Hello... hello... Yes, Harry  yes... everything... everything's fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I should have my head examined. Eight thousand dollars. It's got to be somewhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND VIOLET George has just finished writing something, and is slipping the paper into an envelope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks at him, then says a strange thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reaches up and kisses him on the cheek, leaving lipstick. George opens the door for her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hands it to her) Here you are.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) Character? If I had any character, I'd...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It takes a lot of character to leave your home town and start all over again.  He pulls some money from his pocket, and offers it to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, George, don't...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, now, you're broke, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you want to do, hock your furs, and that hat? Want to walk to New York?  You know, they charge for meals and rent up there just the same as they do in Bedford Falls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (taking money) Yeah  sure...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a loan. That's my business. Building and Loan. Besides, you'll get a job. Good luck to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad I know you, George Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OUTER OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT As George and Violet come through the door, they are being watched by Cousin Tilly, Cousin Eustace and the bank examiner, who is still waiting to go to work on the books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Violet sees the lipstick on George's cheek, and dabs at it with her handkerchief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She exits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Say hello to New York for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah  yeah... sure I will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, let's hear from you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter? Merry Christmas, Vi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Merry Christmas, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . CARTER Mr. Bailey...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Carter, I'm sorry. I'll be right with you. (to Cousin Tilly) Uncle Billy in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, he's in his office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DOORWAY TO UNCLE BILLY'S OFFICE  DAY CLOSE SHOT As George opens the door he sees Uncle Billy frantically looking for the missing envelope. The office is in a mess, drawers are opened, and papers scattered on the floor and on the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George stops short, suddenly aware of the tragic old eyes looking up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy gestures nervously for George to come in. He does so and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Unc... What's going on? The bank examiner's here, and I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in dismay) He's here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, yeah. He wants the accounts payable...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . OUTER OFFICE  DAY MEDIUM SHOT Cousin Tilly is at her switchboard, and Cousin Eustace standing beside her. Carter is still waiting in the doorway to his office.  Suddenly the door opens and George comes striding out. He goes directly to the safe and starts searching, but doesn't find the money. Then he goes to the cash drawer in the counter, and looks through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cousin Eustace runs over to George.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Eustace...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come here a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you see Uncle Billy with any cash last night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He had it on his desk counting it before he closed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS  DAY MEDIUM SHOT Uncle Billy and George are retracing the former's steps through the snow, looking everywhere for the missing money. They pause for a moment on the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They continue on down the street on their search.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Now look, did you buy anything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. Not even a stick of gum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right. All right. Now we'll go over every step you took since you left the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . WINDOW OF POTTER'S OFFICE IN BANK  DAY CLOSE SHOT Potter is peering through the slats of the Venetian blind, watching them as they go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS  DAY MOVING SHOT George and Uncle Billy continue their search.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . UNCLE BILLY'S LIVING ROOM CLOSE SHOT A shabby, old-fashioned, gas-lit room which has been turned almost inside out and upside down in an effort to locate the missing money. Drawers of an old secretary have been pulled out and are on the floor. Every conceivable place which might have been used by Uncle Billy to put the money has been searched. George, his hair rumpled, is feverishly pursuing the search. Uncle Billy is seated behind the desk, his head on his hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy starts sobbing hysterically. George grabs him by the lapels and shakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George jerks him to his feet and shakes him. Uncle Billy stands before him like a frisked criminal, all his pockets hanging out, empty. George's eyes and manner are almost maniacal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He throws Uncle Billy down into his chair, and still shouts at him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George turns and heads for the door, kicking viciously at a waste basket on the floor as he goes. Uncle Billy remains sobbing at the table, his head in his arms.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And did you put the envelope in your pocket?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah... yeah... maybe... maybe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouts) Maybe  maybe! I don't want any maybe. Uncle Billy, we've got to find that money!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (piteously) I'm no good to you, George. I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me. Do you have any secret hiding place here in the house? Someplace you could have put it? Someplace to hide the money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exhausted) I've been over the whole house, even in rooms that have been locked ever since I lost Laura.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (harshly) Listen to me! Listen to me! Think! Think!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sobbing) I can't think any more, George. I can't think any more. It hurts...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (screaming at him) Where's that money, you stupid, silly old fool? Where's the money?  Do you realize what this means? It means bankruptcy and scandal, and prison!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what it means! One of us is going to jail! Well, it's not going to be me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S LIVING ROOM  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Janie (aged eight) is seated at the piano playing "Hark, the Herald Angels Sing," which she practices during the remainder of this scene. There is a Christmas tree all decorated near the fireplace. At a large table Mary is busy putting cellophane bows and decorations on gift packages. At a small table Pete (aged nine) is seated with pad and pencil in the throes of composition.  On the floor Tommy (aged three) is playing with a toy vacuum cleaner. We hear the SOUND of a door open and close. Mary turns and sees George enter the hall, a slight powdering of snow on his head and shoulders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HALL  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT As George comes into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George sneezes violently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary stares at him, aware that something unusual has happened.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello darling.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello Daddy, hello daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating tree) How do you like it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bless you!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you bring the wreath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you bring the Christmas wreath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? What wreath?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Merry Christmas wreath for the window.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (gruffly) No. I left it at the office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is it snowing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, just started.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's your coat and hat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Left them at the office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) Nothing's the matter. Everything's all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIVING ROOM  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT George slumps into an armchair and lifts Tommy onto his lap. Mary is helping Pete decorate the Christmas tree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this scene, George has been sitting in the chair, hugging Tommy to him, and crying quietly. Mary realizes that something is seriously wrong, and breaks off. Janie is thumping away at the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary leads him out toward the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They exit with Tommy hanging onto George's coat-tails, and pulling at him. CAMERA PANS WITH them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, Pete, you're a big boy.  You can put the star up. Way up at the top. That's it.  Fill in that little bare spot right there.  That's it. (to George) Isn't it wonderful about Harry? We're famous, George. I'll bet I had fifty calls today about the parade, the banquet. Your mother's so excited, she...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Must she keep playing that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurt) I have to practice for the party tonight, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mommy says we can stay up till midnight and sing Christmas carols.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you sing, Daddy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to George) Better hurry and shave. The families will be here soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (rising from chair) Families!  I don't want the families over here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on out in the kitchen with me while I finish dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me... excuse me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HALL  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT As they go toward kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Have a hectic day?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bitterly) Oh, yeah, another big red letter day for the Baileys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daddy, the Browns next door have a new car. You should see it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turns on him) Well, what's the matter with our car?  Isn't it good enough for you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (tugging at coat) Excuse me, excuse me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KITCHEN  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT They come through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tommy leaves, and Mary turns to the stove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George paces about the kitchen, worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George goes toward doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We hear his footsteps as he leaves. Mary looks after him, puzzled and concerned, then comes over to Pete.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (annoyed) Excuse you for what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I burped!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, darling, you're excused. Now go upstairs and see what little Zuzu wants.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Zuzu! What's the matter with Zuzu?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, she's got a cold. She's in bed. Caught it coming home from school. They gave her a flower for a prize and she didn't want to crush it so she didn't button up her coat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it, a sore throat or what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a cold. The doctor says it's nothing serious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The doctor? Was the doctor here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I called him right away. He says it's nothing to worry about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is she running a temperature? What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just a teensie one  ninety-nine, six.  She'll be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gosh, it's this old house. I don't know why we don't all have pneumonia. This drafty old barn! Might as well be living in a refrigerator. Why did we have to live here in the first place and stay around this measly, crummy old town?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worried) George, what's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wrong? Everything's wrong! You call this a happy family? Why did we have to have all these kids?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coming in) Dad, how do you spell "frankincense"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouts) I don't know. Ask your mother.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where're you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Going up to see Zuzu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told me to write a play for tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HALL  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE STARTS UP THE STAIRS The knob on the banister comes off in his hand, and for a moment he has an impulse to hurl it into the living room. Then, he replaces the knob, and goes on up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ZUZU'S BEDROOM  NIGHT FULL SHOT The SOUND of Janie at the piano can be heard, the same monotonous rhythm over and over. Zuzu (aged six) is sitting up in her bed, the lamp burning beside her. She is holding her prize flower.  George tiptoes in. Then, as he sees she's awake, he comes over, sitting on the edge of her bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to get out of bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head and presses the flower to her. A few petals fall off. She picks them up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hands him the fallen petals and the flower. He turns his back to Zuzu, pretending to be tinkering with the flower. He sticks the fallen petals in his watch pocket, rearranges the flower, and then turns back to Zuzu.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George puts the flower in a glass of water on the table beside her bed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hi, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what happened to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I won a flower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait now. Where do you think you're going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to give my flower a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, all right. Here, give Daddy the flower. I'll give it a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Daddy... paste it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, all right. Now, I'll paste this together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There it is, good as new.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give the flower a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, will you do something for me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: GEORGE AND ZUZU They whisper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She closes her eyes and relaxes on the bed. George pulls the covers over her. He bends down and his lips touch a tendril of the child's hair. Then he gets up and tiptoes out of the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will you try to get some sleep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sleepy. I want to look at my flower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know  I know, but you just go to sleep, and then you can dream about it, and it'll be a whole garden.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It will?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh-huh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIVING ROOM  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Janie is still pounding with grim determination at the piano. Pete is seated at the table writing. Tommy is playing with his toy vacuum cleaner. The telephone rings.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Telephone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIVING ROOM  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Mary comes in and picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George enters shot, and stands listening to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He snatches the phone from Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts a restraining hand on his arm. He shakes it off. She cannot know that George's tirade against Mrs. Welch is really a tirade against the world, against life itself, against God. Over the phone we hear Mrs. Welch's voice sputtering with protest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary succeeds in wresting the phone from George's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary speaks quickly in to the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But the telephone is suddenly alive with a powerful male voice calling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George hears this and grabs the receiver from Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary once more tries to take the phone from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But before he can think of an insult to top Welch's, we hear a click on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up the receiver, and turns toward the living room. His face is flushed and wet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He yells at Tommy, noisily playing with his vacuum cleaner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janie is still practicing at the piano, monotonously.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll get it. (on phone) Hello. Yes, this is Mrs. Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, thank you, Mrs. Welch. I'm sure she'll be all right. The doctor says that she ought to be out of bed in time to have her Christmas dinner.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that Zuzu's teacher?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hand over receiver) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me speak to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Hello. Hello, Mrs. Welch?  This is George Bailey. I'm Zuzu's father. Say, what kind of a teacher are you anyway?  What do you mean sending her home like that, halfnaked?  Do you realize she'll probably end up with pneumonia on account of you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shocked) George!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is this the sort of thing we pay taxes for  to have teachers like you? Silly, stupid, careless people who send our kids home without any clothes on? You know, maybe my kids aren't the best-dressed kids; maybe they don't have any decent clothes...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, that stupid...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Mrs. Welch. I want to apologize...  hello... hello... (to George) She's hung up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (savagely) I'll hang her up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . WELCH'S VOICE Now, who do you think you are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Mary) Wait a minute. (on phone) Hello? Who is this? Oh, Mr. Welch? Okay, that's fine, Mr. Welch. Gives me a chance to tell you what I really think of your wife.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: George...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raving at her) Will you get out and let me handle this? (into phone  shouting) Hello? Hello? What? Oh, you will, huh?  Okay, Mr. Welch, any time you think you're man enough... Hello? Any...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Daddy, how do you spell "Hallelujah"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouts) How should I know? What do you think I am, a dictionary?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tommy, stop that! Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (savagely) Janie, haven't you learned that silly tune yet? You've played it over and over again.  Now stop it! Stop it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIVING ROOM  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT The room has suddenly become ominously quiet, the only SOUND being George's labored breathing. George goes over to a corner of the room where his workshop is set up  a drawing table, several models of modern buildings, bridges, etc. Savagely he kicks over the models, picks up some books and hurls them into the corner.  Mary and the children watch, horrified. George looks around and sees them staring at him as if he were some unknown wild animal.  The three children are crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary and the children stare at him, stunned by his furious outburst. There is silence in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Janie breaks into sobs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sight of Mary and the children suffering is too much for George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks around him, then quickly goes out the front door of the house. Mary goes to the phone, picks it up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (gasping for breath) I'm sorry, Mary, Janie. I'm sorry. I didn't mean... you go on and practice. Pete, I owe you an apology, too. I'm sorry. What do you want to know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (holding back his tears) Nothing, Daddy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with everybody? Janie, go on. I told you to practice. (shouts) Now, go on, play!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Daddy...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in an outburst) George, why must you torture the children?  Why don't you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bedford, two-four-seven, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is Daddy in trouble?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall I pray for him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Janie, pray very hard.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Me, too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You too, Tommy. (on phone) Hello, Uncle Billy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Potter is seated at his desk, his goon beside him. He is signing some papers. George is seated in a chair before the desk, without a hat or coat, covered lightly with snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George turns and starts out of the office as Potter picks up the phone and dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George is out of the door by now.  CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to Potter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm in trouble, Mr. Potter. I need help.  Through some sort of an accident my company's short in their accounts. The bank examiner's up there today. I've got to raise eight thousand dollars immediately.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (casually) Oh, so that's what the reporters wanted to talk to you about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) The reporters?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. They called me up from your Building and Loan. Oh, there's a man over there from the D.A.'s office, too. He's looking for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) Please help me, Mr. Potter. Help me, won't you please? Can't you see what it means to my family? I'll pay you any sort of a bonus on the loan... any interest. If you still want the Building and Loan, why I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupting) George, could it possibly be there's a slight discrepancy in the books?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir. There's nothing wrong with the books. I've just misplaced eight thousand dollars. I can't find it anywhere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) You misplaced eight thousand dollars?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you notified the police?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir. I didn't want the publicity. Harry's homecoming tomorrow...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (snorts) They're going to believe that one. What've you been doing, George? Playing the market with the company's money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, sir. No, sir. I haven't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it  a woman, then? You know, it's all over town that you've been giving money to Violet Bick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not that it makes any difference to me, but why did you come to me? Why don't you go to Sam Wainwright and ask him for the money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't get hold of him. He's in Europe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, what about all your other friends?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They don't have that kind of money, Mr. Potter. You know that. You're the only one in town that can help me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I see. I've suddenly become quite important. What kind of security would I have, George? Have you got any stocks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) No, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bonds? Real estate? Collateral of any kind?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pulls out policy) I have some life insurance, a fifteen thousand dollar policy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes... how much is your equity in it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Five hundred dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sarcastically) Look at you. You used to be so cocky! You were going to go out and conquer the world! You once called me a warped, frustrated old man. What are you but a warped, frustrated young man? A miserable little clerk crawling in here on your hands and knees and begging for help. No securities  no stocks  no bonds  nothing but a miserable little five hundred dollar equity in a life insurance policy. You're worth more dead than alive. Why don't you go to the riff-raff you love so much and ask them to let you have eight thousand dollar? You know why? Because they'd run you out of town on a rail... But I'll tell you what I'm going to do for you, George. Since the state examiner is still here, as a stockholder of the Building and Loan, I'm going to swear out a warrant for your arrest. Misappropriation of funds manipulation  malfeasance...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, George, go ahead. You can't hide in a little town like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (on phone) Bill? This is Potter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MAIN STREET BEDFORD FALLS  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT George comes out of the bank into the falling snow. He crosses the street, tugs at the door of his old car, finally steps over the door, and drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARTINI'S BAR  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT An attractive little roadside tavern, with the name "Martini's" in neon lights on the front wall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MARTINI'S BAR  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT The place is an Italian restaurant with bar. The bottles sparkle.  There are Christmas greens and holly decorating the place. It has a warm, welcoming spirit, like Martini himself, who is welcoming new arrivals. The booths and the checkered-cloth-covered tables are full. There is an air of festivity and friendliness, and more like a party than a public drinking place. George is seated at the bar  he has had a great deal to drink, far more than he's accustomed to.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: During this, CAMERA MOVES CLOSER to George. Nick, the bartender, is watching him solicitously. Seated on the other side of George is a burly individual, drinking a glass of beer. George is mumbling:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George shakes his head. Martini comes over to his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ugly man next to George, who has been listening, reacts sharply to the name "Bailey."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without any warning, the burly man throws a vicious punch at George, who goes down and out. Martini, Nick and several others rush to pick him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Welch reaches in his pocket for money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick and Martini shove Welch out the door, then run back to help George to his feet. George's mouth is cut and bleeding.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick and Martini try to stop him, but he shrugs them off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George opens the door and exits to the street.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (greeting new customers) Merry Christmas. Glad you came.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about some of that good spaghetti?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: God... God... Dear Father in Heaven, I'm not a praying man, but if you're up there and you can hear me, show me the way. I'm at the end of my rope. Show me the way, God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (friendly) Are you all right, George? Want someone to take you home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (worried) Why you drink so much, my friend? Please go home, Mr. Bailey. This is Christmas Eve.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bailey? Which Bailey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is Mr. George Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to George) And the next time you talk to my wife like that you'll get worse. She cried for an hour. It isn't enough she slaves teaching your stupid kids how to read and write, and you have to bawl her out...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (furious) You get out of here, Mr. Welch!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now wait... I want to pay for my drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind the money. You get out of here quick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You hit my best friend. Get out!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You all right, George?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stunned) Who was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's gone. Don't worry. His name is Welch.  He don't come in to my place no more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh  Welch. That's what I get for praying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The last time he come in here. You hear that, Nick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, you bet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's my insurance policy? (finds it in pocket) Oh, here...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, Please, don't go out this way, Mr. Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no  you don't feel so good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please don't go away  please!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . RESIDENTIAL STREET  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT George's car comes along the empty street, through the falling snow, suddenly swerves and crashes into a tree near the sidewalk of a house.  George gets out to look at the damage, and savagely kicks at the open door of the car, trying to shut it. The noise brings the owner of the house running out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do you think you're doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: George stands unsteadily near the car, shaken by the accident. The front lights are broken and the fender is ripped. George stands dully looking at the damage. The owner comes up, looking at his tree. He leans over to examine the damages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George staggers off down the street, paying no attention to the man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (with indignation) Now look what you did. My greatgrandfather planted this tree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, you... Hey, you! Come back here, you drunken fool! Get this car out of here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BRIDGE OVER RIVER  NIGHT MEDIUM LONG SHOT George is crossing the approach to the bridge when a truck swings around the corner and nearly hits him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The truck turns onto the bridge, and George takes a narrow catwalk at the railing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what's the matter with you? Look where you're going!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: George has stopped by the railing at the center of the bridge. The snow is now falling hard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RIVER  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT CAMERA SHOOTING DOWN from George's angle TO the water, dotted with floating ice, passing under the bridge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRIDGE AT RAILING  NIGHT CLOSEUP  GEORGE He stares down at the water, desperate, trying to make up his mind to act. He leans over looking at the water, fascinated, glances furtively around him, hunches himself as though about to jump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From above George a body hurtles past and lands in the water with a loud splash. George looks down, horrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George quickly takes off his coat and dives over the railing into the water.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (from river) Help! Help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE George comes up, sees the man flailing about in the water, and CAMERA PANS WITH him as he swims toward the man.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Help! Help! Help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . TOLL HOUSE ON BRIDGE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT The toll house keeper, hearing the cries for help, comes running out on the bridge with a flashlight, which he shines on the two figures struggling in the water below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . RIVER  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT The man in the water is Clarence, the angel whose voice we have heard speaking from Heaven. George reaches him, grabs hold of him, and starts swimming for shore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TOLL HOUSE ON BRIDGE  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT  GEORGE, CLARENCE, AND THE TOLLKEEPER George is seated before a wood-burning stove before which his clothes are drying on a line. He is in his long winter underwear.  He is sipping a mug of hot coffee, staring at the stove, cold, gloomy and drunk, ignoring Clarence and the tollkeeper, preoccupied by his near suicide and his unsolved problems.  Clarence is standing on the other side of the stove, putting on his undershirt. This is a ludicrous seventeenth century garment which looks like a baby's night shirt  with embroidered cuffs and collar, and gathered at the neck with a drawstring. It falls below his knees.  The tollkeeper is seated against the wall eyeing them suspiciously. Throughout the scene he attempts to spit, but each time is stopped by some amazing thing Clarence does or says.  Clarence becomes aware that his garment is amazing the tollkeeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tollkeeper, about to spit, is stopped in the middle of it by this remark. Clarence, secretly trying to get George's attention, now picks up a copy of "Tom Sawyer" which is hanging on the line, drying. He shakes the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tollkeeper stares at him incredulously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George looks up, surprised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George and the tollkeeper react to this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leans forward to spit, but is stopped by Clarence's next statement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tollkeeper becomes increasingly nervous. George casually looks at the strange smiling little man a second time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George's hand goes to his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tollkeeper's chair slips out from under him with a crash. He has been leaning against the wall on it, tipped back on two legs.  Tollkeeper rises and makes his way warily out the door. From his expression he looks like he'll call the nearest cop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George rubs his head with his hand, to clear his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at Clarence standing beside him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarence is not getting far with George. He glances up, paces across the room, thoughtfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Clarence speaks this line, the snow stops falling outside the building, a strong wind springs up which blows open the door to the shack. Clarence runs to close the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Clarence speaks, George cocks his head curiously, favoring his deaf ear, more interested in his hearing than in what Clarence has said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George feels his ear as Clarence talks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't have time to get some stylish underwear. My wife gave me this on my last birthday. I passed away in it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Tom Sawyer's drying out, too. You should read the new book Mark Twain's writing now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'd you happen to fall in?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't fall in. I jumped in to save George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You what? To save me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I did, didn't I? You didn't go through with it, did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go through with what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Suicide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's against the law to commit suicide around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, it's against the law where I come from, too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where do you come from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Heaven. (to George) I had to act quickly; that's why I jumped in. I knew if I were drowning you'd try to save me. And you see, you did, and that's how I saved you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (offhand) Very funny.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your lip's bleeding, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, I got a bust in the jaw in answer to a prayer a little bit ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (comes around to George) Oh, no  no  no. I'm the answer to your prayer. That's why I was sent down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (casually interested) How do you know my name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I know all about you. I've watched you grow up from a little boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you, a mind reader or something?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, who are you, then?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clarence Odbody, A-S-2.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Odbody... A-S-2. What's that A-S-2?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Angel, Second Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue
