dialogue.raw_text: (to tollkeeper) Cheerio, my good man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, brother. I wonder what Martini put in those drinks?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, what's with you? What did you say just a minute ago? Why'd you want to save me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I was sent down for. I'm your guardian angel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wouldn't be a bit surprised.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ridiculous of you to think of killing yourself for money. Eight thousand dollars.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) Yeah... just things like that. Now how'd you know that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you  I'm your guardian angel. I know everything about you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you look about like the kind of an angel I'd get. Sort of a fallen angel, aren't you? What happened to your wings?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I haven't won my wings yet. That's why I'm an angel Second Class.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know whether I like it very much being seen around with an angel without any wings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I've got to earn them, and you'll help me, won't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (humoring him) Sure, sure. How?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By letting me help you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only one way you can help me. You don't happen to have eight thousand bucks on you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, no, no. We don't use money in Heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's right, I keep forgetting. Comes in pretty handy down here, bub.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, tut, tut, tut.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I found it out a little late. I'm worth more dead than alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now look, you mustn't talk like that. I won't get my wings with that attitude. You just don't know all that you've done. If it hadn't been for you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (interrupts) Yeah, if it hadn't been for me, everybody'd be a lot better off. My wife, and my kids and my friends. (annoyed with Clarence) Look, little fellow, go off and haunt somebody else, will you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you don't understand. I've got my job...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (savagely) Aw, shut up, will you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) Hmmm, this isn't going to be so easy. (to George) So you still think killing yourself would make everyone feel happier, eh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dejectedly) Oh, I don't know. I guess you're right. I suppose it would have been better if I'd never been born at all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What'd you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said I wish I'd never been born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you mustn't say things like that. You... (gets an idea) ...wait a minute. Wait a minute. That's an idea. (glances up toward Heaven) What do you think? Yeah, that'll do it.  All right. (to George) You've got your wish. You've never been born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking upward) You don't have to make all that fuss about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've never been born. You don't exist.  You haven't a care in the world.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No worries  no obligations  no eight thousand dollars to get  no Potter looking for you with the Sheriff.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: GEORGE AND CLARENCE George indicates his bad ear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George feels his lip, which shows no sign of the recent cut he received from Welch. He is now thoroughly confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George feels the clothes on the line.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They start dressing. George interrupts himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Say something else in that ear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bending down) Sure. You can hear out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, that's the doggonedest thing... I haven't heard anything out of that ear since I was a kid. Must have been that jump in the cold water.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your lip's stopped bleeding, too, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about that... What's happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: George looks around, as though to get his bearings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's stopped snowing out, hasn't it? What's happened here? (standing up) Come on, soon as these clothes of ours are dry...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our clothes are dry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you know about that? Stove's hotter than I thought. Now, come on, get your clothes on, and we'll stroll up to my car and get...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm sorry. I'll stroll. You fly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't fly. I haven't got any wings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You haven't got your wings. Yeah, that's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STREET  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT This is the same empty street where George's car swerved into the tree near the sidewalk. George and Clarence come into shot and up to the spot where George had left his car smashed against the tree. George looks around, but his car is nowhere to be seen, and the tree is undamaged.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (puzzled) Well, this is where I left my car and it isn't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have no car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I had a car, and it was right here.  I guess somebody moved it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: AT CURB The owner of the house passes with some Christmas packages under his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The owner bends down to examine the trunk of the tree, then straightens up and smells George's breath. He backs away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The owner proceeds toward his house. George is completely bewildered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts his arm around Clarence, and they start off up the road.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (politely) Good evening.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, say... Hey... where's my car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I beg your pardon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My car, my car. I'm the fellow that owns the car that ran into your tree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What tree?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, what tree? This tree.  Here, I ran into it. Cut a big gash in the side of it here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must mean two other trees. You had me worried. One of the oldest trees in Pottersville.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (blankly) Pottersville? Why, you mean Bedford Falls.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I mean Pottersville. (sharply) Don't you think I know where I live? What's the matter with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I don't know. Either I'm off my nut, or he is... (to Clarence) ...or you are!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It isn't me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, maybe I left the car up at Martini's. Well, come on, Gabriel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as they go) Clarence!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Clarence! Clarence!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NICK'S BAR  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT It is Martini's place, but almost unrecognizable. The cheerful Italian feeling is gone. It is now more of a hard-drinking joint, a honky-tonk. Same bar, tables have no covers. People are lower down and tougher. Nick the bartender is behind the bar. George and Clarence come in. George does not notice the difference, but Clarence is all eyes and beaming. They go up to the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two people leave the bar as they approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he says this, Nick leans over the counter and puts his left fist nearly in Clarence's eye. Clarence is puzzled by this conduct.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick turns away to get the drinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick is listening suspiciously to this conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick stops pouring the drinks, bottle poised in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cash register bell rings off stage. Clarence reacts to the SOUND of the bell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George glances up at Nick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nick slams the bottle down on the counter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as they come in) That's all right. Go on in. Martini's a good friend of mine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's a place to sit down. Sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nick is wiping off the bar as they sit down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, hello, Nick. Hey, where's Martini?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want a martini?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no, Martini. Your boss. Where is he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatient) Look, I'm the boss. You want a drink or don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay  all right. Double bourbon, quick, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. (to Clarence) What's yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just thinking... (face puckers up with delicious anticipation) It's been so long since I...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impatient) Look, mister, I'm standing here waiting for you to make up your mind.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (appreciatively) That's a good man. I was just thinking of a flaming rum punch. No, it's not cold enough for that. Not nearly cold enough...  Wait a minute... wait a minute... I got it. Mulled wine, heavy on the cinnamon and light on the cloves. Off with you, me lad, and be lively!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, look mister, we serve hard drinks in here for men who want to get drunk fast.  And we don't need any characters around to give the joint atmosphere. Is that clear?  Or do I have to slip you my left for a convincer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to George) What's he talking about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (soothingly) Nick  Nick, just give him the same as mine. He's okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter with him. I never saw Nick act like that before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll see a lot of strange things from now on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, yeah. Hey, little fellow  you worry me. You got someplace to sleep?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't huh? Well, you got any money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No wonder you jumped in the river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I jumped in the river to save you so I could get my wings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, that's right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh-oh. Somebody's just made it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Made what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Every time you hear a bell ring, it means that some angel's just got his wings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, I think maybe you better not mention getting your wings around here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why? Don't they believe in angels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at Nick) A... Yeah, but... you know...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why should they be surprised when they see one?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Nick) He never grew up. He's... (to Clarence) How old are you, anyway, Clarence?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Two hundred and ninety-three... (thinks) ...next May.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That does it! Out you two pixies go, through the door or out the window!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Nick. What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (angrily) And that's another thing. Where do you come off calling me Nick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, Nick, that's your name, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that got to do with it? I don't know you from Adam's off ox. (sees someone come in) Hey, you! Rummy! Come here! Come here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A small wreck of a man, with weak, watery eyes. Obviously a broken-down panhandler, his hat in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GEORGE He can hardly believe his eyes. It is Gower the druggist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (to Gower) Didn't I tell you never to come panhandling around here? Nick picks up a seltzer bottle, and squirts Gower in the face with it. The crowd laugh brutally. Gower smiles weakly as the soda runs off his face.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: BACK TO SHOT NICK AT THE BAR NICK

direction.raw_text: George, horrified, leaps up and goes over to Gower.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bouncers throw Gower out the front door. George rushes back to the bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Gower! Mr. Gower! This is George Bailey! Don't you know me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to his bouncers) Throw him out. Throw him out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) Hey, what is... Hey, Nick, Nick... Isn't that Mr. Gower, the druggist?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, that's another reason for me not to like you. That rumhead spent twenty years in jail for poisoning a kid. If you know him, you must be a jailbird yourself. (to his bouncers) Would you show these gentlemen to the door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure. This way, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NICK'S BAR  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT George and Clarence come flying through the door and land in the snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NICK'S BAR  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Nick at the cash register, busily ringing the bell.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey! Get me! I'm giving out wings!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NICK'S BAR  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT George and Clarence lying in the snow. George has a strange, puzzled look on his face. They remain for a moment as they landed, looking at each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George catches a glimpse of the front of the building with the neon sign over the door. It now reads "NICK'S PLACE" instead of "MARTINI'S." George and Clarence get to their feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points to the sign, and looks at Clarence. Clarence sort of hangs his head. George fixes him with a very interested look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George, still looking at him, goes up to him and pokes his arm.  It's flesh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George rapidly searches his pockets for identification, but without success.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George feverishly continues to turn his pockets inside out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George is completely befuddled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He starts off. Clarence rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George strides off hurriedly. Clarence slowly follows him, glancing up toward Heaven as he goes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You see, George, you were not there to stop Gower from putting that poison into the...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, I wasn't there? I remember distinctly...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) What the... hey, what's going on around here?  Why, this ought to be Martini's place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, who are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (patiently) I told you, George. I'm your guardian angel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, yeah, I know. You told me that. What else are you? What... are you a hypnotist?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, of course not.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well then, why am I seeing all these strange things?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you understand, George? It's because you were not born.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then if I wasn't born, who am I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're nobody. You have no identity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean, no identity? My name's George Bailey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is no George Bailey. You have no papers, no cards, no driver's license, no 4-F card, no insurance policy... (he says these things as George searches for them) George looks in his watch pocket.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're not there, either.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Zuzu's petals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You've been given a great gift, George. A chance to see what the world would be like without you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shaking his head) Now wait a minute, here. Wait a minute here. As, this is some sort of a funny dream I'm having here. So long, mister, I'm going home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Home? What home?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (furious) Now shut up! Cut it out! You're... you're... you're crazy! That's what I think... you're screwy, and you're driving me crazy, too! I'm seeing things. I'm going home and see my wife and family. Do you understand that? And I'm going home alone!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How'm I doing, Joseph. Thanks. (pause) No, I didn't have a drink!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STREET  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT  GEORGE MOVES INTO THE SCENE The sign bearing the name of the town reads: "Pottersville." George looks at it in surprise, then starts up the street toward the main part of town. As he goes, CAMERA MOVES WITH him. The character of the place has completely changed. Where before it was a quiet, orderly small town, it has now become in nature like a frontier village. We see a SERIES OF SHOTS of night clubs, cafes, bars, liquor stores, pool halls and the like, with blaring jazz MUSIC issuing from the majority of them. The motion picture theatre has become a burlesque house. Gower's drugstore is now a pawnbroker's establishment, and so on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George stops before what used to be the offices of the Building and Loan.  There is a garish electric sign over the entrance reading: "Welcome Jitterbugs." A crowd of people are watching the police, who are raiding the place, and dragging out a number of screaming women, whom they throw into a patrol wagon. George talks to one of the cops:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey... hey. Where did the Building and Loan move to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Building and what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Bailey Building and Loan. It was up there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They went out of business years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: George sees the struggling figure of Violet Bick, arrayed as a tart, being dragged into the patrol wagon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cop shoves George to one side. He looks around and sees Ernie's taxi cruising slowly by.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Violet! (to the cop) Hey, listen  that's Violet Bick!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that girl!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Ernie  Ernie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . STREET  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Ernie stops the cab, and George enters it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ernie, take me home. I'm off my nut!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a much harder Ernie) Where do you live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, now, doggone it, Ernie, don't you start pulling that stuff. You know where I live. Three-twenty Sycamore. Now hurry up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Three-twenty Sycamore?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah  yeah  hurry up. Zuzu's sick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right.  He pulls down the flag on the meter and starts the cab.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CAB  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSEUP  GEORGE AND ERNIE Ernie is puzzled by the stranger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernie turns to driving, but he's worried about his passenger. As he passes the burlesque house he sees Bert the cop standing beside his police car. Attracting his attention, he motions to Bert to follow him, indicating he has a nut in the back. Bert gets into his car and follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look here, Ernie, straighten me out here.  I've got some bad liquor or something.  Listen to me now. Now, you are Ernie Bishop, and you live in Bailey Park with your wife and kid? That's right, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suspiciously) You seen my wife?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exasperated) Seen your wife? I've been to your house a hundred times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, bud, what's the idea?  I live in a shack in Potter's Field and my wife ran away three years ago and took the kid...  And I ain't never seen you before in my life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay. Just step on it. Just get me home.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . GEORGE'S HOUSE  NIGHT MEDIUM LONG SHOT The taxi pulls up to the curb and stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cab is parked. George gets out and looks at the house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is this the place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course it's the place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, this house ain't been lived in for twenty years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HOUSE  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT George is stopped momentarily by the appearance of the house. Windows are broken, the porch sags, one section of the roof has fallen, doors and shutters hang askew on their hinges. Like a doomed man, George approaches the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . CAB  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT The police car has pulled up beside the cab, and Bert and Ernie stand watching George's actions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernie switches on the spotlight on his cab, and turns the beam toward the old house.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's up, Ernie?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, but we better keep an eye on this guy. He's bats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HALLWAY GEORGE'S HOUSE  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT The interior of the house is lit up here and there, ghostlike, by Ernie's spotlight. No furniture, cobwebs, wallpaper hanging and swinging  stairs are broken and collapsed. In a voice that sounds like a cry for help, George yells out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clarence suddenly appears leaning against a wall.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mary! Mary! Tommy! Pete! Janie! Zuzu! Where are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're not here, George. You have no children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (ignoring him) Where are you? (then, to Clarence) What have you done with them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DOORWAY  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Bert is standing in the entrance, with his gun in his hand. Ernie is a few feet behind him, ready to run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rushes toward Bert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bert tries to lead George away by the arm, but George struggles with him, trying to explain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bert raises his gun to hit George on the head. As he does so, Clarence darts in and fixes his teeth in Bert's wrist, forcing him to let George go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George dashes out of the house and down the street, as Bert grapples with Clarence, and they fall to the ground, wrestling. We see Bert kneeling, trying to put handcuffs on Clarence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly Clarence disappears from under Bert's hands. Bert gets up, amazed by his vanishing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ernie's hair is now standing on end with fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs out of the scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, put up your hands. No fast moves. Come on out here, both of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bert! Thank heaven you're here!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stand back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bert, what's happened to this house? Where's Mary? Where's my kids?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (warningly) Watch him, Bert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (bewildered) Bert  Ernie! What's the matter with you two guys? You were here on my wedding night. You, both of you, stood out here on the porch and sung to us, don't you remember?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (nervously) Think I'd better be going.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, now why don't you be a good kid and we'll take you in to a doctor. Everything's going to be all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Bert, now listen to me. Ernie, will you take me over to my mother's house? Bert, listen! (gesturing to Clarence) It's that fellow there  he says he's an angel  he's tried to hypnotize me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hate to do this, fella.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Run... George! Run, George!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help! Joseph, help!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, shut up!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Help, oh Joseph, help! Joseph!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where'd he go? Where'd he go? I had him right here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stammering) I need a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, which way'd they go? Help me find 'em.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BAILEY HOME  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT George runs up the path to the front door of the house and raps on the door. He rings the bell and taps on the glass, when his attention is caught by a sign on the wall reading: "Ma Bailey's Boarding House."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: GEORGE AT THE DOOR The door opens and a woman appears. It is Mrs. Bailey, but she has changed amazingly. Her face is harsh and tired. In her eyes, once kindly and understanding, there is now cold suspicion. She gives no sign that she knows him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a cruel blow to George.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to close the door, but George stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She slams the door shut in George's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother? What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mother, this is George. I thought sure you'd remember me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (coldly) George who? If you're looking for a room there's no vacancy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Mother, Mother, please help me. Something terrible's happened to me. I don't know what it is. Something's happened to everybody. Please let me come in. Keep me here until I get over it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get over what? I don't take in strangers unless they're sent here by somebody I know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (desperate) Well, I know everybody you know. Your brother-in-law, Uncle Billy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suspiciously) You know him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, sure I do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When'd you see him last?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Today, over at the house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a lie. He's been in the insane asylum ever since he lost his business.  And if you ask me, that's where you belong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HOUSE  NIGHT MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT George stands a moment, stunned. Then he turns and runs out to the sidewalk, until his face fills the screen. His features are distorted by the emotional chaos within him. We see Clarence leaning on the mail box at the curb, holding his volume of "Tom Sawyer" in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk out of scene.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Strange, isn't it?  Each man's life touches so many other lives, and when he isn't around he leaves an awful hole, doesn't he?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (quietly, trying to use logic) I've heard of things like this. You've got me in some kind of a spell, or something.  Well, I'm going to get out of it. I'll get out of it. I know how, too. I... the last man I talked to before all this stuff started happening to me was Martini.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know where he lives?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure I know where he lives. He lives in Bailey Park.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . CEMETERY  NIGHT MEDIUM SHOT George and Clarence approach the tree from which the "Bailey Park" sign once hung. Now it is just outside a cemetery, with graves where the houses used to be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The two walk into the cemetery.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure this is Bailey Park?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, I'm not sure of anything anymore. All I know is this should be Bailey Park. But where are the houses?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as they go) You weren't here to build them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: MOVING SHOT George wandering like a lost soul among the tombstones, Clarence trotting at his heels. Again George stops to stare with frightened eyes at:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A TOMBSTONE Upon it is engraved a name, Harry Bailey. Feverishly George scrapes away the snow covering the rest of the inscription, and we read: "IN MEMORY OF OUR BELOVED SON  HARRY BAILEY 1911-1919" CLOSE SHOT  GEORGE AND CLARENCE CLARENCE Your brother, Harry Bailey, broke through the ice and was drowned at the age of nine. George jumps up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That's a lie! Harry Bailey went to war! He got the Congressional Medal of Honor! He saved the lives of every man on that transport.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sadly) Every man on that transport died. Harry wasn't there to save them because you weren't there to save Harry. You see, George, you really had a wonderful life.  Don't you see what a mistake it would be to throw it away?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: GEORGE AND CLARENCE GEORGE Clarence...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George grabs Clarence by the coat collar and shakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George lets Clarence go, and runs off. Clarence falls to the ground, where he rubs his neck.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, George?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where's Mary?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, well, I can't...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how you know these things, but tell me  where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you know where she is, tell me where my wife is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not supposed to tell.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (becoming violent) Please, Clarence, tell me where she is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're not going to like it, George.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shouting) Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's an old maid. She never married.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (choking him) Where's Mary? Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in self-defense) She's just about to close up the library!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to himself) There must be some easier way for me to get my wings.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LIBRARY  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Mary comes out the door, then turns and locks it. We see George watching her from the sidewalk. Mary is very different no buoyancy in her walk, none of Mary's abandon and love of life.  Glasses, no make-up, lips compressed, elbows close to body. She looks flat and dried up, and extremely self- satisfied and efficient.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George, as he watches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George and Mary, on the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks up, surprised, but, not recognizing him, continues on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary starts to run away from him, and he follows, desperately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He catches up to her, grabs her by the arms, and keeps a tight grip on her. She struggles to free herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary breaks away from him, and dashes into the first door she comes to, the Blue Moon Bar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mary!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary! Mary!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary, it's George! Don't you know me?  What's happened to us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (struggling) I don't know you! Let me go!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mary, please! Oh, don't do this to me.  Please, Mary, help me. Where's our kids? I need you, Mary! Help me, Mary!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BLUE MOON  NIGHT CLOSE SHOT Small tables, booths, perhaps a counter. It is crowded. Many of the people are the same who were present during the run on the Building and Loan. Mary comes running in, screaming. The place goes into an uproar. George comes in, practically insane. Some of the men grab and hold on to him.

direction.raw_text: Uncle Billy Mary and the crowd come into the living room. A table stands in front of George. George picks up Zuzu to protect her from the mob. Uncle Billy dumps the basketful of money out onto the table  the money overflows and falls all over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rest of the crowd all greet George with greetings and smiles.  Each one comes forward with money. In their pockets, in shoe boxes, in coffee pots. Money pours onto the table pennies, dimes, quarters, dollar bills  small money, but lots of it. Mrs. Bailey and Mrs. Hatch push toward George. More people come in. The place becomes a bedlam. Shouts of "Gangway  gangway" as a new bunch comes in and pours out its money. Mary stands next to George, watching him. George stands there overcome and speechless as he holds Zuzu. As he sees the familiar faces, he gives them sick grins.  Tears course down his face. His lips frame their names as he greets them.

The Herald Angels Sing," and the entire crowd joins in the singing. We see a SERIES OF SHOTS of the various groups singing the hymn, and some people are still coming in and dropping their money on the table. Carter, the bank examiner, makes a donation; the sheriff sheepishly looks at George and tears his warrant in small pieces. In the midst of this scene, Harry, in Naval uniform, enters, accompanied by Bert, the cop.

direction.raw_text: George, still holding Zuzu in his arms, glances down at the pile of money on the table. His eye catches something on top of the pile, and he reaches down for it. It is Clarence's copy of "Tom Sawyer." George opens it and finds an inscription written in it: "Dear George, remember no man is a failure who has friends. Thanks for the wings, Love Clarence."
